# syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `add-component-via-interceptor`

## question

Can you get the add-component-via-interceptor of the iiop-openjdk?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `add-component-via-interceptor`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `add-component-via-interceptor` attribute value.
* `add-component-via-interceptor` attribute description: indicates whether `ssl` components should be added by an `ior` interceptor (on) or not (off).
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=add-component-via-interceptor)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `transactions`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `transactions` attribute value.
* `transactions` attribute description: indicates whether the transactions interceptors are to be installed (full or spec) or not (none). the value 'full' enabled `jts` while 'spec' enables a spec compliant mode (non `jts`) that rejects incoming transaction contexts.
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=transactions)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `security`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `security` attribute value.
* `security` attribute description: `iiop-openjdk.security=indicates` whether the security interceptors are to be installed (elytron) or not (none). identity and client are legacy security configurations which are valid for compatibility reasons but are no longer supported.
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=security)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `client-supports`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `client-supports` attribute value.
* `client-supports` attribute description: value that indicates the client `ssl` supported parameters (none, `serverauth`, `clientauth`, `mutualauth`).
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=client-supports)`

## LLM reply

```
/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=add-component-via-interceptor)
```

* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `number-to-reclaim` attribute value.

* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `high-water-mark`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `high-water-mark` attribute value.
* `high-water-mark` attribute description: `tcp` connection cache parameter. each time the number of connections exceeds this value orb tries to reclaim connections. number of reclaimed connections is specified by `tcp-number-to-reclaim` property. if this property is not set then it is configured as `openjdk` orb default.
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=high-water-mark)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `detect-replay`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `detect-replay` attribute value.
* `detect-replay` attribute description: indicates whether the transport must require replay detection or not. valid values are 'none', 'supported' and 'required'.
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=detect-replay)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `persistent-server-id`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `persistent-server-id` attribute value.
* `persistent-server-id` attribute description: persistent id of the server. persistent object references are valid across many `activactions` of the server and they identify it using this property. as a result of that: many activations of the same server should have this property set to the same value, different server instances running on the same host should have different server ids.
* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=persistent-server-id)`

* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `transactions` attribute value.
* `transactions` attribute description: indicates whether the transactions interceptors are to be installed (full or spec) or not (none). the value 'full' enabled `jts` while 'spec' enables a spec compliant mode (non `jts`) that rejects incoming transaction contexts.

* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=jts)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `iiop-openjdk` `server-supports`
* Retrieve the `iiop-openjdk` `server-supports` attribute value.
* `server-supports` attribute description: value that indicates the server `ssl` supported parameters (none, `serverauth`, `clientauth`, `mutualauth`).

* operation: `/subsystem=iiop-openjdk:read-attribute(name=client-supports)`

* `jgroups-stack` attribute description: references the name of a `jgroups` channel factory.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/jgroups-discovery-group=<jgroups-discovery-group name>:read-attribute(name=jgroups-stack)`

Can you get the last value queue of the messaging activemq server myServer address setting myAddressSetting?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `last-value-queue`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `last-value-queue` attribute value.
* `last-value-queue` attribute description: defines whether a queue only uses last values or not
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=last-value-queue)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `queue` `expiry-address`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `queue` `expiry-address` attribute value.
* `expiry-address` attribute description: the address to send the `queue's` expired messages to.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/queue=<queue name>:read-attribute(name=expiry-address)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-read-page-bytes`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-read-page-bytes` attribute value.
* `max-read-page-bytes` attribute description: how much memory the messages read from paging can take on the queue whenever more messages are needed.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=max-read-page-bytes)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `auto-create-queues`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `auto-create-queues` attribute value.
* `auto-create-queues` attribute description: determines whether `activemq` should automatically create a queue corresponding to the `address-settings` match when a producer or a consumer is tries to use such a queue.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=auto-create-queues)`

## LLM reply

```
/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=myServer/address-setting=myAddressSetting:read-attribute(name=last-value-queue)
```

# syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-delivery-attempts`

* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `address-full-policy` attribute value.
* `address-full-policy` attribute description: determines what happens when an address where `max-size-bytes` is specified becomes full. (page, drop or block)

* `auto-create-addresses` attribute description: determines whether `activemq` should automatically create an addresses corresponding to the `address-settings` match when a producer or a consumer is tries to use such a queue.

Can you get the page max cache size of the messaging activemq server myServer address setting myAddressSetting?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `page-max-cache-size`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `page-max-cache-size` attribute value.
* `page-max-cache-size` attribute description: the number of page files to keep in memory to optimize io during paging navigation.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=page-max-cache-size)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-read-page-bytes`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-read-page-bytes` attribute value.
* `max-read-page-bytes` attribute description: how much memory the messages read from paging can take on the queue whenever more messages are needed.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=max-read-page-bytes)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `address-full-policy`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `address-full-policy` attribute value.
* `address-full-policy` attribute description: determines what happens when an address where `max-size-bytes` is specified becomes full. (page, drop or block)
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=address-full-policy)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-size-bytes`
* Retrieve the `messaging-activemq` `server` `address-setting` `max-size-bytes` attribute value.
* `max-size-bytes` attribute description: the max bytes size.
* operation: `/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=<server name>/address-setting=<address-setting name>:read-attribute(name=max-size-bytes)`

## LLM reply

```
/subsystem=messaging-activemq/server=myServer/address-setting=myAddressSetting:read-attribute(name=page-max-cache-size)
```

* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `node-identifier`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `node-identifier` attribute value.

* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `process-id-socket-binding`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `process-id-socket-binding` attribute value.

* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `commit-markable-resource` `name`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `commit-markable-resource` `name` attribute value.
* `name` attribute description: defines the database table name used for storing ids associated with this `cmr` resource. the default value for naming the database table is '`xids`'.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions/commit-markable-resource=<commit-markable-resource name>:read-attribute(name=name)`

## LLM reply

```

```

Can you get the number of timed out transactions of the transactions?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `number-of-timed-out-transactions`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `number-of-timed-out-transactions` attribute value.
* `number-of-timed-out-transactions` attribute description: the number of transactions that have rolled back due to timeout.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=number-of-timed-out-transactions)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `number-of-application-rollbacks`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `number-of-application-rollbacks` attribute value.
* `number-of-application-rollbacks` attribute description: the number of transactions that have been rolled back by application request. this includes those that timeout, since the timeout behavior is considered an attribute of the application configuration.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=number-of-application-rollbacks)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `default-timeout`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `default-timeout` attribute value.
* `default-timeout` attribute description: the default timeout, in seconds, for a new transaction started by the transaction manager (see also the '`maximum-timeout`' attribute).
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=default-timeout)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `maximum-timeout`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `maximum-timeout` attribute value.
* `maximum-timeout` attribute description: if the '`default-timeout`' attribute is zero then this value is used for setting the maximum timeout value (in seconds) for newly started transactions.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=maximum-timeout)`

## LLM reply

```
/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=number-of-timed-out-transactions)
```

# syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `object-store-path`

## question

Can you get the object-store-path of the transactions?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `object-store-path`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `object-store-path` attribute value.
* `object-store-path` attribute description: denotes a path where the transaction manager object store should store data. by default the value is treated as relative to the path denoted by the '`relative-to`' attribute. when the '`relative-to`' attribute is undefined the value is considered an absolute path. this setting is valid when default or journal store is used. `it's` not used when the `jdbc` journal store is used.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=object-store-path)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `object-store-relative-to`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `object-store-relative-to` attribute value.
* `object-store-relative-to` attribute description: references a global path configuration in the domain model, defaulting to the application server data directory (`jboss.server.data.dir`). the value of the '`object-store-path`' attribute will be treated as relative to this path. undefine this attribute to disable the default behavior and force the value of the '`object-store-path`' attribute to be treated as an absolute path.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=object-store-relative-to)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `node-identifier`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `node-identifier` attribute value.
* `node-identifier` attribute description: used to set the node identifier. each `xid` that the transaction manager creates will have this identifier encoded within it and ensures the transaction manager will only recover branches which match the specified identifier. it is imperative that this identifier is unique between application server instances which share either an object store or access common resource managers.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=node-identifier)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `log-store` `log-store` `transactions` `type`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `log-store` `log-store` `transactions` `type` attribute value.
* `type` attribute description: the type name under which this record is stored.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions/log-store=log-store/transactions=<transactions name>:read-attribute(name=type)`

## LLM reply

```
/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=object-store-path)
```

# syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `process-id-socket-binding`

## question

Can you get the process-id-socket-binding of the transactions?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `process-id-uuid`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `process-id-uuid` attribute value.
* `process-id-uuid` attribute description: indicates a strategy used for obtaining a unique identifier needed for creation of transaction instances. when true then the transaction manager generates the transaction id based on process id (`pid`). when set to false then the transaction manager generates the transaction id based on the referenced socket binding, `i.e`. the attribute '`process-id-socket-binding`' is required.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=process-id-uuid)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `process-id-socket-binding`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `process-id-socket-binding` attribute value.
* `process-id-socket-binding` attribute description: the name of the socket binding to use if the transaction manager should use a `socket-based` generation of transaction id. will be 'undefined' if '`process-id-uuid`' is 'true'; otherwise must be set.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `socket-binding`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `socket-binding` attribute value.
* `socket-binding` attribute description: references an existing socket binding that the transaction manager will listen on for recovery requests.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=socket-binding)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `status-socket-binding`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `status-socket-binding` attribute value.
* `status-socket-binding` attribute description: references an existing socket binding that the transaction manager will listen on for transaction status requests.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=status-socket-binding)`

## LLM reply

```
/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding)
```

# syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `use-hornetq-store`

## question

Can you get the use-hornetq-store of the transactions?

## directives

* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `use-hornetq-store`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `use-hornetq-store` attribute value.
* `use-hornetq-store` attribute description: use the journal store for writing transaction logs. set to true to enable and to false to use the default log store type. the default log store is normally one file system file per transaction `log.it's` alternative to `jdbc` based store.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=use-hornetq-store)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `hornetq-store-enable-async-io`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `hornetq-store-enable-async-io` attribute value.
* `hornetq-store-enable-async-io` attribute description: whether `asyncio` should be enabled for the journal store.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=hornetq-store-enable-async-io)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `use-journal-store`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `use-journal-store` attribute value.
* `use-journal-store` attribute description: use the journal store for writing transaction logs. the journal store consists of one file for all the transactions. set to true to enable. note that the server will not boot if both '`use-journal-store`' and '`use-jdbc-store`' attributes are set to true. if both are set to false then the default `filesystem` based store will be used.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=use-journal-store)`
* syntax of the operation to get the `transactions` `use-jdbc-store`
* Retrieve the `transactions` `use-jdbc-store` attribute value.
* `use-jdbc-store` attribute description: use the `jdbc` store for writing transaction logs. data is saved in the database indicated by the '`jdbc-store-datasource`' attribute. set to true to enable. note that the server will not boot if both '`use-journal-store`' and '`use-jdbc-store`' attributes are set to true. if both are set to false then the default `filesystem` based store will be used.
* operation: `/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=use-jdbc-store)`

```
/subsystem=transactions:read-attribute(name=use-hornetq-store)
```
